Fact: Horses have the largest eyes of any land mammal.
Horses can run shortly after birth.
Horses can sleep both lying down and standing up.
A horse’s teeth take up a larger amount of space in their head than their brain.
Horses have a highly developed sense of balance.
A horse's heart typically weighs between 6-10 pounds.
Horses can rotate their ears 180 degrees.
Horses typically have 205 bones in their skeleton.
A horse's hoof is analogous to a human's fingernail; it keeps growing and needs to be clipped.
Horses communicate their feelings through facial expressions.
Horses are herd animals with a clear hierarchy within the group.
Horses use their tails for communication and as a defense against flies and other insects.
Horses have been domesticated for over 5000 years.
Horses have a blind spot directly in front of them.
The four natural paces for a horse are walk, trot, canter, and gallop.
A horse’s teeth can give a good estimate of its age.
The average lifespan of a horse is between 25 to 30 years.
Horses have a strong sense of memory.
Horses have been used in warfare for thousands of years.
The gestation period for a horse is about 11 to 12 months.
Horses have been represented in art for thousands of years.
Horses are obligate nasal breathers, meaning they must breathe through their nostrils and cannot breathe through their mouths.
The fastest recorded sprinting speed of a horse was 55 mph.

Horses have been used in various therapeutic programs, including equine therapy and rehabilitation programs for individuals with physical, emotional, and developmental challenges and for prison inmates.
A horse's foot continues to grow until it is fully mature, which can take four to six years.
Horses have been used in various sports, including polo and equestrian events.
Horses have been integral to many cultures and have played key roles in historical events and development of trade routes.
Historically, horses have been used extensively for pulling wagons, carriages, and other transportation, as well as for farm work.
The word 'chivalry' comes from 'cheval,' the French word for horse.
Horses have three different types of gaits: walk, trot, and gallop.
Horses are measured in units called hands. One hand is equal to four inches.
Horses are capable of seeing nearly 360 degrees around them.
Horses have a unique digestive system, with a small stomach but very long intestines.
Horses are vegetarians and have a diet mostly based on grass and grains.
Horses are known for their agility and speed.
A horse’s hooves need to be cleaned regularly to prevent infection.
Horses are highly social animals.
Horses need to be dewormed regularly as they are prone to parasite infestations.
The largest organ in the horse's body is the skin.
A horse’s body contains 12 gallons of blood.
Horses can be trained to perform complex tasks.
The oldest known horse lived to be 62 years old.
Horses have been featured in many works of literature and film.
A horse's 'frog,' the part of the hoof that touches the ground, acts as a shock absorber and helps with circulation.
Horses can recognize their own reflection.
Horses have a well-developed sense of hearing.
Horses have whiskers on their noses and around their eyes which they use for sensing their environment.
A horse’s coat gets thicker in the winter to protect it from cold temperatures.
Horses can swim, although they are not naturally inclined to do so.
Horses can see better at night than humans can.
Horses have a unique 'stay apparatus' in their legs that allows them to sleep standing up without falling over.
Horses can't vomit due to the strength of the muscles around their esophagus.
Horses have a unique hoof mechanism that promotes blood circulation throughout their body.
Horses' large nostrils allow for increased airflow when running.
Horses have a keen sense of touch, thanks to the vibrissae around their nostrils and lips.
A horse’s hoof grows at a rate of about one centimeter per month.
Horses need daily exercise to maintain good health and spirits.
Horses have an excellent sense of direction.
Horses have an average resting heart rate of 30 to 40 beats per minute.
Horses can express mood, intent, or attention through ear position.
The design of many modern roads and highways was influenced by paths originally created for horse travel.
Horses can interpret human emotions and respond accordingly.
The teeth of horses never stop growing.
A horse’s lungs can hold up to 55 liters of air.
Horses have a relatively small stomach for their size, which is why they eat little and often.
Horses have 18 pairs of ribs.
The left and right sides of a horse's brain function independently, which means they may not recognize a person or object seen from the opposite side.
Horses have a high tolerance for pain, which can make it difficult to detect when they're injured.
In terms of biomechanics, horses can either 'pace' or 'trot' based on the sequence in which their legs move.
A horse's legs contain no muscle below the knees and hocks, only bones, tendons and ligaments.
The most common injuries in horses are to the legs and hooves.
Colic is a major cause of death in horses, it refers to any abdominal pain, but generally refers to gastrointestinal discomfort.
A horse's liver functions almost like a human's, filtering toxins from the body.
Horses, like humans, can suffer from allergies.
Horses have a 'flight response' when frightened, a holdover from when they were prey animals.
Horses cannot see all colors; they are red-green color blind similar to some humans.
Horses need a lot of water - they drink at least 25 gallons every day.
Horses have more bones in their necks than giraffes; they both have seven cervical vertebrae, but some of the horse's are bifurcated, which means they split in two.
Horses have a gland called the 'chestnut' on their legs, the function of which is unknown.
Horses don’t have a gall bladder.
Despite having a long and muscular back, horses' backs are relatively weak compared to their overall body strength.
The horse's brain weights about 22 ounces, roughly half the weight of a human brain.
A horse's skin is about 12-15% of its total body weight.
Horses' hooves are made from the same protein that comprises human hair and nails - keratin.
Horses have a gland in their eye socket called the 'Harderian gland' which helps clean and protect the eye.
The horse's intestines are about 90 feet long.
Horses have only one stomach, unlike cows, and it is small in size compared to their overall body size.
Horses can suffer from a variety of sleep disorders, including sleep apnea and narcolepsy.
The horse's spleen is a reservoir for red blood cells, releasing them when the horse is in 'flight mode' for extra oxygenation.
Horses are at risk of developing ulcers due to their high-stress nature and the high acidity of their stomach.
A horse's hock joint in its hind leg functions similarly to the human ankle, despite looking like it would be the equivalent to a knee.
Horses have a relatively slow breathing rate, averaging around 12-16 breaths per minute.
Horses are prone to certain eye issues, including equine recurrent uveitis (ERU) which is the most common cause of blindness in horses.
A horse's kidneys filter around 40-45 liters of blood every hour.
Horses can suffer from a condition known as 'heaves,' similar to asthma in humans, due to dust and mold spores.
Horses have more back problems than most animals because riders sit on their backs.
Horses are at risk of developing laminitis, a painful condition affecting the hooves.
Horses have a special 'trick' muscle, the panniculus, that allows them to shake off flies in a wave motion without using much energy.
A horse's brain is divided into left and right hemispheres like a human's, and each side operates independently.
Horses have unique dental patterns that can be used, similarly to fingerprints in humans, for identification.
Horses are used in various therapy programs as they can help improve physical, emotional, and social skills.
Horses can engage in 'mutual grooming' where two horses will stand next to each other and groom each other's coats.
A horse's teeth take up more space in their head than their brain.
Contrary to popular belief, horses do not swallow their tongues while running. This myth likely arose due to the use of tongue ties in horse racing.
A horse's heart can weigh up to 10 pounds.
The hyoid apparatus in a horse, which supports the tongue and larynx, is the only bone in the body not connected to any other bone.
Horses have a third eyelid called the nictitating membrane that helps protect and moisten the eye.
A horse's hoof will take 9-12 months to regrow completely if damaged.
A horse's 'frog,' the V-shaped part of the hoof, helps in shock absorption and circulation.
A healthy horse at rest will take in about 10 gallons of air per minute.
The age of a horse can be determined with some accuracy by examining its teeth.
A horse's lungs are so large that a human could fit inside them.
Horses are capable of producing about 10 gallons of saliva every day.
The smallest bone in a horse's body is the auditory ossicle in the ear.
Horses have been trained for various jobs, including police work and therapy work.
Horses sweat through their skin to cool down, just like humans.
Horses have a tendon in their leg known as the 'superficial digital flexor tendon' that acts as a spring for efficient running.
A horse's hair grows fastest in the summer.
Horses can see more colors than dogs or cats.
Horses can detect subtle changes in the position of a rider's body.
Horses played a crucial role in the development of modern postal systems, being the primary mode of transport for mail in the past.
The number of red blood cells in a horse's body is about three times that of a human.
Horses have 'hollow hairs' in their winter coats that help insulate them in cold weather.
Horses are extremely social animals and often bond closely with other horses in their herd. They can become distressed when separated from their companions.
Despite their large size, horses are quite capable jumpers.
Equine Assisted Psychotherapy (EAP) is a type of therapy that makes use of horses to help promote emotional growth and learning.
The horse's top speed is influenced by its stride length and stride frequency.
The horse's whiskers serve as sensory devices and help the horse to feel what's in its immediate environment.
Horses use their tail to signal their mood to other horses.
Horses are able to recognize their own reflection in a mirror.
Horses have played a significant role in warfare throughout history.
A horse's body contains about 80 liters of blood.
A horse's coat can become lighter or darker based on environmental factors, such as sun exposure.
Horses are vulnerable to both heat stroke and frostbite.
Horses have a 'stay apparatus' that allows them to relax muscles and rest while standing upright.
A horse's hocks are the equivalent of human ankles and heels.
A horse's teeth grind down over time, and can develop sharp edges if not filed or 'floated' regularly.
Horses have a structure in their throat called a larynx that helps them produce vocal sounds.
Horses have two soft tissue structures on either side of their neck called 'jugular furrows' where you can see the pulse.
When a horse's ears are pinned back flat, it usually means the horse is angry, annoyed or frightened.
In times of war, horses have been used to carry messages, pull artillery, supply wagons and provide reconnaissance.
Horses' hooves have a shock-absorbing structure known as the 'lateral cartilage.'
The horse's 'frog' part of the hoof is thought to aid in circulation of blood.
Horses can contract Lyme disease from ticks.
When horses look like they're laughing, they're actually performing a special nose-enhancing technique known as 'flehmen' to determine whether a smell is good or bad.
A horse’s hoof is always growing and needs to be trimmed by a farrier every 6-8 weeks.
Horses have been used in therapeutic riding programs to help people with disabilities gain improved coordination, balance, and strength.
Horses played an important role in transportation throughout history, particularly before the invention of the steam engine.
In historical times, the value of a knight's warhorse could be as much as that of a small airplane today.
Horses are capable of making 17 distinct facial movements to express their feelings, a number higher than dogs (16), but less than humans (27).
Wild horses typically gather in groups of 3 to 20 animals, led by a mature male, known as a 'stallion.'
Feral horses are descendants of once-domesticated horses that have run free for generations.
Unlike domestic horses, wild horses roam vast distances and can cover up to 20 miles in a day searching for food.
The gestation period of wild horses is the same as domestic horses, about 11-12 months.
Wild horse populations have a 'harem structure,' with one stallion and multiple mares and their offspring.
In certain parts of the world, roundups are held to control the population of wild horses.
Wild horses are often identified by distinct markings or brands that are unique to their herd.
Wild horses have longer, rougher coats than their domestic counterparts due to exposure to varying weather conditions.
Unlike domestic horses, wild horses must forage for their food, which can include grasses, shrubs, and even tree bark.
The lifespan of wild horses is typically shorter than that of domestic horses due to harsh living conditions and lack of veterinary care.
Wild horses have been known to dig water holes in dry riverbeds to reach drinking water.
In many parts of the world, wild horses are considered a symbol of freedom and the spirit of the wilderness.
The behaviors and social structures of wild horse herds have been extensively studied as a model for understanding the dynamics of other social animals.
Young wild horse males, once ousted from their birth herd, often form 'bachelor herds' until they can acquire their own females.
Predators of wild horses include wolves, mountain lions, and bears.
The Przewalski's horse, native to Mongolia, is the only true wild horse species that exists today, with all others being feral descendants of domestic horses.
The Bureau of Land Management in the United States manages and protects wild horse and burro populations on public lands.
There are more than 60,000 wild horses in the United States, the majority of which are found in the Western states and Nevada.
Feral horses in North America are descendants of horses brought by European explorers and settlers.
The Australian Brumby, a feral horse, is named after James Brumby, a soldier and horse breeder in the early settlement of New South Wales.
Many wild horse populations are threatened by habitat loss due to human encroachment and development.
Wild horses have complex social structures and communication systems, which researchers are still working to fully understand.
Adoption programs exist to help manage wild horse populations and give captured wild horses a second chance at life in a domestic setting.
Wild horses will often roll in dust or mud to create a protective layer against insects.
Wild horses use 'stud piles,' or communal dung heaps, as a form of territorial marking.
Horses have the largest eyes among all land mammals.
Horse's eyes are positioned on the sides of their head, giving them a wide field of vision.
Horses can see nearly 360 degrees around them due to the placement of their eyes.
Despite their wide field of vision, horses have two blind spots: directly in front of them and directly behind them.
The horse's eyes can adjust to sudden changes in light, but it takes longer than it does for human eyes.
Horses see colors differently than humans. They can see blues and greens, but have difficulty distinguishing between yellows and greens and blues and grays.
Horses are believed to see in a similar way to red-green colorblind humans.
A horse’s eyesight is generally far-sighted, rather than near-sighted.
Horses use their ears to direct their gaze and focus on something specific.
The shape and size of a horse's eyes can affect its field of vision.
A horse's eye contains three eyelids: the upper, lower, and the third eyelid, also known as a nictitating membrane.
Horses have a reflective layer behind their retina called tapetum lucidum, which enhances their night vision.
A horse's eyes are more sensitive to movement than human eyes.
A healthy horse's eye is clear and bright, with no or minimal tearing.
Horses often use their sense of hearing in combination with their vision to identify potential threats.
The horse's cornea, the outer layer of the eye, is the largest of any land mammal and makes up a larger portion of the eye surface.
The large size of the horse's eye contributes to its sensitivity to dust, wind, and abrupt changes in light.
A horse's eye is surrounded by a protective bone called the orbital rim.
Horses can't focus their eyes like humans. They change focus by changing the angle of their heads.
There are several conditions and diseases that can affect a horse's eyesight, including cataracts, glaucoma, and uveitis.
Horses' eyes are expressive and can indicate their mood, much like their ears.
Some horses have blue eyes, a trait that is associated with certain coat patterns, like pintos.
When a horse is under stress or frightened, the whites of their eyes may become more visible.
The size and lateral placement of a horse's eyes can limit its depth perception.
Horses tend to rely more heavily on monocular vision (using each eye separately) rather than binocular vision (using both eyes together).
The oldest known evidence of horse domestication dates back over 5,000 years to the Botai culture in present-day Kazakhstan.
The Arabian Peninsula is considered the birthplace of the Arabian horse, one of the oldest and most influential horse breeds in the world.
The countries with the highest number of horse breeds include the United States, which has a diverse range of breeds, followed by France and Germany.
The Lipizzaner horses, famous for their performances at the Spanish Riding School in Vienna, Austria, have been bred for over 400 years.
The Thoroughbred breed, known for its speed and agility, originated in 18th-century England through the selective breeding of Arabian, Barb, and Turkoman horses.
The Lusitano breed, native to Portugal, has a long history of being used in bullfighting and classical dressage due to its athleticism and agility.
The Friesian horse, originating in the Netherlands, has been selectively bred for over 800 years and is known for its striking black coat and majestic appearance.
The American Quarter Horse, developed in the United States, is the most popular breed in the country and is known for its versatility in Western riding disciplines.
The Caspian horse, believed to be one of the oldest breeds in the world, was rediscovered in 1965 in Iran after being thought extinct for centuries.
The culture of the Mongols was deeply connected to horses, and their breeding and horsemanship skills played a pivotal role in their military conquests in the 13th century.
The Andalusian horses, originating in Spain, were highly prized as war horses during the Renaissance period.
The Hanoverian breed, developed in Germany, is renowned for its success in Olympic equestrian sports, particularly dressage and show jumping.
The Icelandic Horse, bred in Iceland, is known for its unique fifth gait called the tölt, which provides a smooth and comfortable ride.
The Welsh Pony and Cob breed, hailing from Wales, has different sections based on height and type, including Section A, B, C, and D.
The Australian Stock Horse, bred in Australia, evolved from the sturdy horses brought by European settlers and played a vital role in Australian bush work.
The Appaloosa breed, developed by the Nez Perce Native American tribe in the United States, is known for its distinctive spotted coat patterns.
The Shire Horse, originating in the United Kingdom, is one of the largest horse breeds and was historically used for heavy pulling and agricultural work.
The Morgan horse, originating in the United States, is the first recognized American horse breed, known for its versatility and endurance.
The Hackney Horse breed, originating in the United Kingdom, is famous for its high-stepping trot and elegance, making it popular in carriage driving competitions.
The Selle Français, developed in France, is a versatile sport horse breed known for its success in show jumping, dressage, and eventing.
The Akhal-Teke, originating in Turkmenistan, is known for its striking metallic sheen coat and is often referred to as the 'golden horse.'
The Belgian Draft horse, originating in Belgium, is a powerful and muscular breed often used for heavy draft work and pulling competitions.
The Camargue horse, native to the marshy regions of southern France, is an ancient breed known for its agility, endurance, and white or gray coat.
The Mustang, descended from Spanish horses brought to the Americas, roams freely in the wild and is protected by legislation in the United States.
The Azteca breed, developed in Mexico, is a versatile horse that combines characteristics of Andalusian and Quarter Horse, excelling in both dressage and ranch work.
